review_title: Really good company to work for
pros:
The RSC takes a genuine interest in the well-being and satisfaction of their employees - I would say this is exceptional compared to some other employers. Salaries are very competitive for the field, to me the strategic direction for both the Publishing directorate and the whole organisation, and how my role fits into this, seems very clear. I find my role interesting and varied, and it gives me plenty of development opportunities and the chance to work with a diverse range of colleagues rather than being stuck in a “silo”.

Work-life balance is great. Something you might hear is that the RSC is “all about the people” - I found this to be the case. The expectations of you are communicated properly and accurately reflect the job description.
cons: Nothing significant. I guess to add balance, it can seem hard to progress upwards, and change of pace can feel slow - how much of a ‘con’ that is depends on the individual, but something to be aware of when deciding if a company’s right for you.

review_title: A once happy place to work has become a corporate mill. Make the most of the opportunities ther but don't stay too long.
pros: Subsidised meals. Generous pension scheme. Rapid promotion possible if your face fits. Young friendly staff - good social life. Cambridge is a nice place to live.
cons: Inexperienced staff promoted beyond their capabilities. What middle management lacks in charisma or inspired leadership it makes up for in micromanagement. Forget that the RSC is a registered charity - the corporate culture has become excessive and seems to only serve the senior staff and council rather than the chemical sciences. All staff are subject to constant monitoring by computer activitiy, and pulled up if they appear to be underperforming. Social life can be a bit cliquey - depending on which university you went to. High proportion of PhDs doing very menial jobs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The RSC is full of friendly people who are incredibly social. The people are the best thing about working here. There are opportunities for training, career progression and they have good systems. I worked in various roles over my 3 years in publishing and sales and these experiences have helped with progressing my career post-RSC. Pension is fantastic and as RSC member (which is free to staff) you have access to the Careers Specialists.
cons: Communication between all levels of management and staff is very poor. It is a very corporate charity with recent restructuring and recruitment pauses. There is a lot of movement between roles and high turn over of staff. Many people have to repeatedly apply for permanent and secondment roles within a competitive environment. If you are a non-scientist then career progression is limited, even outside publishing. If you are an internal job mover there is no flexibility in negotiating your salary.

cons: My role requires a reasonably high level of travel, but I was aware of this in advance and despite this  feel I have a very positive work-life balance.
